conversation.content: 那个，呃，你也是第一次来这种"寻找人生目标"的活动吗，还是说你是常客？
天哪，对，第一次。我的心理医生基本上是逼我来的，在我今年辞掉第三份工作之后。Apparently "professional quitter" isn't a viable career path，谁知道呢？
等等，一年内三份工作？那还挺厉害的。
厉害还是可悲，这得看你怎么看了。投资银行，兽医助理，还有——这个最奇葩——专业巧克力品尝师。None of them stuck, obviously.
[delighted] 巧克力品尝师？真的有这种工作？
[sad] 对啊，那个，呃，其实是我的梦想工作，until I realized I was just... 就是在吃自己的情绪，literally. 原来每周吃12磅巧克力并不能填补内心的空虚，it just makes you really, really sick.
12磅？我的天。
[chuckle] 对吧？最糟糕的是我现在连看到士力架都会有，怎么说，战争创伤后遗症。So what's your story——是什么把你拖到这个自助地狱的角落的？
我女儿。她7岁，问我做什么让我开心。
哎哟。小孩子就是有这种本事，用简单的问题把你彻底摧毁，don't they? 我侄子有次问我为什么大人要假装喜欢自己的工作——我完全答不上来。
你有孩子？
[belly laugh] 没有没有，那是我侄子！你能想象我有孩子吗？我连一个职业都坚持不了四个月——a tiny human would be doomed.
也许那就是你的目标啊。不承诺。
哇，这个... 嗯。从来没人把我的慢性犹豫不决说成是有潜在目的的。Usually it's more like "grow up" or "pick something already"，或者我最爱听的，"你都35岁了，拜托！"
[high-pitched] 35？你看起来最多28！
啊，嗯，apparently existential crisis is great for the skin——谁需要视黄醇啊，when you have crushing anxiety about your life choices, 对吧？但说真的，呃，你跟你女儿说什么了？
什么都没说。我就哭了。
哎呀。对，那... 那挺难受的。But honestly, 哭可能是对那个问题最真实的回答了。Most people just lie and say "spreadsheets" or whatever.
[sarcastic] 电子表格确实给我带来巨大的快乐，actually.
看，现在有进展了！Maybe your purpose is to, 怎么说，通过眼泪和数据透视表来革新数据输入——stranger things have happened, 真的。

original_conversation.content: So, uh, first time at one of these "find your life's purpose" things too, or are you a regular?
Oh god, yeah, first time. My therapist basically forced me to come after I, um, quit my third job this year. Apparently "professional quitter" isn't a viable career path, who knew?
Wait, three jobs in one year? That's actually impressive.
Impressive or pathetic, depends on your perspective I guess. Investment banking, veterinary assistant, and—this is the weird one—professional chocolate taster. None of them stuck, obviously.
[delighted] A chocolate taster? That was real?

[sad] Yeah, it was, uh, it was actually my dream job until I realized I was just... eating my feelings, literally. Turns out consuming twelve pounds of chocolate a week doesn't actually fill the existential void, it just makes you really, really sick.
Twelve pounds? Jesus.
[chuckle] Right? The worst part is I can't even look at a Snickers bar anymore without, like, having war flashbacks. So what's your story—what dragged you to this particular corner of self-help hell?
My daughter. She's seven and asked me what I do that makes me happy.
Oof. Kids have this way of, um, absolutely destroying you with simple questions, don't they? Mine asked me once why adults pretend to like their jobs—I had no answer.
You have kids?
[belly laugh] No, no, that was my nephew! Can you imagine me with actual children? I can't even commit to a career path for more than four months—a tiny human would be doomed.
Maybe that's your purpose though. Being uncommitted.

Wow, that's... huh. Nobody's ever framed my chronic indecision as potentially purposeful before. Usually it's more like "grow up" or "pick something already" or my personal favorite, "you're thirty-five for Christ's sake."
[high-pitched] Thirty-five? You look maybe twenty-eight!
Ah, well, apparently existential crisis is great for the skin—who needs retinol when you have crushing anxiety about your life choices, right? But seriously, um, what did you tell your daughter?
Nothing. I just cried.
Oh man. Yeah, that's... that's rough. But honestly, crying might be the most authentic response anyone's given to that question. Most people just lie and say "spreadsheets" or whatever.
[sarcastic] Spreadsheets do bring me tremendous joy, actually.
See, now we're getting somewhere! Maybe your purpose is to, I don't know, revolutionize data entry through the power of tears and pivot tables—stranger things have happened, frankly.
